references: Key related works. Most of the previous studies on FCB are discussed in Sec.Â 2.2, and more comprehensively reviewed in AppendixÂ B. We note that these FCB designs with tailored FL protocols in previous works sometimes can achieve near-optimal performance bounds in specific settings, while our proposed FedIGW is more practical and extendable. We believe these two types of designs are valuable supplements to each other. A high-level comparison between the proposed FedIGW and existing FCB designs is listed in TableÂ 1. Additionally, while this work was being developed, the paper (Agarwal etÂ al., 2023) was posted, which also proposes to have a decoupled FL component in FCB. However, Agarwal etÂ al. (2023) mainly focuses on empirical investigations, while our work offers valuable complementary contributions by conducting thorough theoretical analyses.

S2.T2.footnotes: AE: arm elimination; Gen. Linear: generalized linear model; AGD: accelerated gradient descent
references: Upon a holistic review of these works, it becomes apparent that each of them employs a particular FL protocol to update the parameters required by CB. To be more specific, a periodically alternating design between CB and FL is commonly adopted as reflected in Fig.Â 1: CB (collects one epoch of data in parallel) â†’â†’\rightarrow FL (proceeds with CB data together and outputs CBâ€™s parameterization) â†’â†’\rightarrow updated CB (collects another epoch of data in parallel) â†’â†’\rightarrow â‹¯â‹¯\cdots. A compact summary, including the components of FL and CB employed in previous FCB works, is presented in TableÂ 2.

The main underlying reason for selecting IGW as the CB component is that it is a regression-based CB algorithm, i.e., IGW only requires a learned reward function f^lsuperscript^ğ‘“ğ‘™\hat{f}^{l} for the CB interaction in one epoch lğ‘™l. The canonical FL framework with an optimization perspective is exactly targeted at learning such a function via collaboratively solving Eqn.Â (1), which thus can be integrated with IGW. In contrast, previous FCB designs are predominated by UCB-based CB components as reflected in TableÂ 2. However, obtaining the upper confidence bounds (UCBs) estimates for an unknown reward function is not usually the target of the canonical FL framework. Thus, tailored FL components are developed to fulfill this purpose, e.g., sharing covariance matrices to obtain UCBs for linear reward functions.

S5.T3.caption: Table 3: The context dimension and number of arms in Bibtex and Delicious
S5.T3.table:
Task Context dimension Number of arms
Bibtex 1835 159
Delicious 500 983
references: In this section, we report the empirical performances of FedIGW on two distinct real-world multi-label classification datasets, Bibtex (Katakis etÂ al., 2008) and Delicious (Tsoumakas etÂ al., 2008), which are also used in other practical CB investigations such as Cortes (2018). The aim of CB in these experiments is considered to be recommending one of the correct labels at any given time. Especially, in the experiments, at each time step, a context is randomly sampled from the dataset while the true labels are concealed from the agents. The agents then determine which label to select (i.e., pull one arm) with their CB algorithms; thus the number of arms is the number of possible labels in each dataset. Upon pulling one arm, a reward of 111 is granted if the pulled arm corresponds to one of the true labels, while a reward of 00 is granted otherwise. From TableÂ 3, we can observe that these tasks are challenging given their high-dimensional contexts (>500absent500>500) and large numbers of arms (>150absent150>150). Additional experimental details and results are discussed in AppendixÂ G.

A2.T4.caption: Table 4: A comparison of settings and results of federated linear bandits; note that FedIGW is not specifically designed and optimized to handle linear reward functions as previous designs.
A2.T4.footnotes: â€ â€ \dagger: assuming a homogeneous and known context distribution for all agents;â€¡â€¡\ddagger: solving the global ridge regression via directly sharing aggregated local rewards and covariance matrices as in the other listed works;â™­â™­\flat: solving the global ridge regression via distributed accelerated gradient descent;
references: A detailed comparison of the obtained regrets and the amounts of communicated real numbers is provided in TableÂ 4. It can be observed that adapting FedIGW to the specific case of linear bandits does not provide the same near-optimal performance as in previous works. This is not a surprise as (single-agent) IGW itself has not yet been shown to achieve the lower-bound performance of linear bandits, while the previous works are largely built upon the nearly optimal LinUCB design (Abbasi-Yadkori etÂ al., 2011). However, as noted in RemarkÂ 3.2, IGW only requires a learned reward function, instead of complicated data analytics such as UCB, which grants it great flexibility to better incorporate FL advancements and handle more general scenarios beyond the linear setting.

references: For practical conveniences, instead of selecting a theoretically sound but sophisticated choice of Î³ğ›¾\gamma for FedIGW as in TheoremÂ 4.1, we set it as a constant hyper-parameter and perform some preliminary manual selections with the final adopted values reported in TableÂ 5. We believe this approach is more practically appealing as it does not need to scale Î³ğ›¾\gamma consistently; a similar choice of using constant Î³ğ›¾\gammaâ€™s is also adopted in Agarwal etÂ al. (2023).

Multiple standard FL protocols including FedAvg (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), SCAFFOLD (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020) and FedProx (Li etÂ al., 2020a) are adopted as the FL component in FedIGW. During each FL process, the local batch size, the number of communications, and the local learning rate are specified in TableÂ 5. Moreover, the epoch length is designed to be growing exponentially as in CorollariesÂ 4.2, D.8 and E.2, i.e., Ï„l=2lsuperscriptğœğ‘™superscript2ğ‘™\tau^{l}=2^{l}, while culminating at an upper limit of 409640964096 to maintain timely updates.
